title: Bug: Probably wrong fix of ESLint's prefer-template warning

labels.name: accepted
labels.description: There is consensus among the team that this change meets the criteria for inclusion

labels.name: archived due to age
labels.description: This issue has been archived; please open a new issue for any further discussion

labels.name: autofix
labels.description: This change is related to ESLint's autofixing capabilities

body:
### Environment

Node version: 16.9.1
npm version: 7.24.0
Local ESLint version: 8.0.0.beta.2
Global ESLint version: none
Operating System: Windows 10 21H1




### What parser are you using?

Other

### What did you do?

ESLint raises a warning `ESLint: Unexpected string concatenation.(prefer-template)`:

for the given code:

```js
res.setHeader("content-security-policy",
		"default-src 'self' https://*.google.com;"
		+ "script-src 'self' 'unsafe-eval' 'unsafe-inline' https://*.google.com;"
		+ "connect-src 'self' https://*.google.com;"
		+ "frame-ancestors 'none';"
		+ "report-to " + policyViolationReport
		+ ";");
```

### What did you expect to happen?

When I click on **ESLint: Fix: `prefere-template`** in IDE (or  `eslint --config eslintrc.json --fix app.js`), I expect to get:

```js
res.setHeader("content-security-policy",
		`"default-src 'self' https://*.google.com;"`
		+ `"script-src 'self' 'unsafe-eval' 'unsafe-inline' https://*.google.com;"`
		+ `"connect-src 'self' https://*.google.com;"`
		+ `"frame-ancestors 'none';"`
		+ `"report-to "${policyViolationReport};`);
```

### What actually happened?

The result in fact:

```js
res.setHeader("content-security-policy",
		`${"default-src 'self' https://*.google.com;"
		+ "script-src 'self' 'unsafe-eval' 'unsafe-inline' https://*.google.com;"
		+ "connect-src 'self' https://*.google.com;"
		+ "frame-ancestors 'none';"
		+ "report-to "}${  policyViolationReport
		 };`);
```

The possible issues are:
1. Unwanted space `${  policyViolationReport`
2. Unwanted line break for the closing clause ` };` of the last literal variable:

```js
+ "report-to "}${  policyViolationReport
 };`);
```

3. For some reason, `"default-src 'self' https://*.google.com;"` is represented as a placeholders (`${expression}`), while in fact it's just a text, not a variable in contrast to the `policyViolationReport`, which really should be represented as a literal placeholder â€” `${policyViolationReport}`.

4. BTW, the line break with literals can be implemented without concatenation symbols `+`, e.g.:

```js
`string text line 1
 string text line 2`
```

### Participation

- [ ] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

### Additional comments

File for reproduction:
[app.js.txt](https://github.com/eslint/eslint/files/7192726/app.js.txt)
